required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Significance of Blood-tryptase and c-Kit Mutation in Insect Venom Immunotherapy
clinical_study.official_title: The Significance of Blood-tryptase Levels and c-Kit Mutation in the Evaluation of Prognosis and Adverse Reactions in Subjects Undergoing Venom Immunotherapy for Insect Allergy

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators wish to evaluate the association between tryptase values as well as c-Kit mutation and adverse effects in the course of immunotherapy. The investigators also intend to assess the effect of immunotherapy on tryptase levels.

detailed_description.textblock: According to the presently available reports there is an association between systemic allergic responses to hymenoptera venom and elevated tryptase levels or c-Kit mutation. The presence of these findings may imply the existence of mast cell activation syndrome or mastocytosis. Therefore, baseline tryptase evaluation has become standard evaluation in patients with systemic responses. Meir Medical Center is the only hospital in Israel in which tryptase can be measured. Consequently, the Meir Clinic has accumulated considerable data with regards to tryptase levels in subjects with allergy to hymenoptera venom. The investigators wish to evaluate the association between tryptase values as well as c-Kit mutation and adverse effects in the course of immunotherapy. The investigators also intend to assess the effect of immunotherapy on tryptase levels.

primary_outcome.measure: The association between tryptase values/c-Kit mutation and immunotherapy adverse events will be evaluated using blood sample analysis and patient medical records.

secondary_outcome.measure: The association between tryptase values/c-Kit mutation and severity of index sting event will be evaluated using blood sample analysis and patient medical records.

arm_group.description: The study group will include all the subjects receiving routine venom immunotherapy at the Meir Medical Center Allergy Clinic.

biospec_descr.textblock: Biospecimen will include 5 ml of venous whole blood drawn for measurement of serum tryptase and leukocyte c-Kit mutation.

study_pop.textblock: The population will include all the subjects undergoing venom immunotherapy at the Clinic of Allergy and Clinical Immunology, Meir Medical Center.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- history of systemic response to hymenoptera sting.
- subject under current or planned venom immunotherapy.
Exclusion Criteria:
- previously diagnosed mast cell disorder

reference.citation: Cichocka-Jarosz E, Sanak M, Szczeklik A, Brzyski P, Pietrzyk JJ. Impact of Hymenoptera venom allergy and the effects of specific venom immunotherapy on mast cell metabolites in sensitized children. Ann Agric Environ Med. 2014;21(2):294-301. doi: 10.5604/1232-1966.1108594.

Niedoszytko M, de Monchy J, van Doormaal JJ, Jassem E, Oude Elberink JN. Mastocytosis and insect venom allergy: diagnosis, safety and efficacy of venom immunotherapy. Allergy. 2009 Sep;64(9):1237-45. doi: 10.1111/j.1398-9995.2009.02118.x. Epub 2009 Jul 21. Review.

results_reference.citation: Zanotti R, Lombardo C, Passalacqua G, Caimmi C, Bonifacio M, De Matteis G, Perbellini O, Rossini M, Schena D, Busa M, Marcotulli MC, Bil√≤ MB, Franchini M, Marchi G, Simioni L, Bonadonna P. Clonal mast cell disorders in patients with severe Hymenoptera venom allergy and normal serum tryptase levels. J Allergy Clin Immunol. 2015 Jul;136(1):135-9. doi: 10.1016/j.jaci.2014.11.035. Epub 2015 Jan 17.
